tn.ref: What is this you have done to us?
tn.text: The people of the tribe of Ephraim were rebuking Gideon with this rhetorical question for not including them in his army. This can be expressed as a statement. AT: "You have not treated us fairly." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
Here "Midian" represents the Midianite army. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: they had a violent argument with him
tn.text: they had a violent argument with him they argued angrily with him" or "they rebuked him severely"
Gideon replies to the men from Ephraim.

tn.ref: What have I done now compared to you?
tn.text: Gideon uses this question to honor the people of Ephraim. AT: "I have done very little compared with what you have done!" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])

tn.ref: Are not the gleanings of Ephraim's grapes better than the full grape harvest of Abiezer?
tn.text: Gideon was calming the people of Ephraim with this rhetorical question. AT: "Certainly the grapes you people of Ephraim gleaned are better than what we the descendants of Abiezer gathered from the whole harvest!" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]]

tn.ref: Are not the gleanings of Ephraim's grapes better than the full grape harvest of Abiezer?
tn.text: Gideon and his army defeating the Medianites is spoken of as if it were a grape harvest. The people of Ephraim killing Oreb and Zeeb at the end of the battle is spoken of as if they were gleaning grapes at the end of the harvest. AT: "What you people of Ephraim did at the end of the battle is more important than what we descendants of Abiezer did at the beginning." ([[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

This is the name of one of Gideon's ancestors. Gideon used his name to refer to Abiezer's descendants and their land. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])
Translate these names as you did in [[:en:bible:notes:jdg:07:24|7:25]].

tn.ref: What have I accomplished compared to you?
tn.text: Gideon uses this question to honor the people of Ephraim. This can be expressed as a statement. AT: "What you have done is more important than what I have done." See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
"became less"
"the 300 men" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_numbers]])
The word "pursuit," an abstract noun, can be expressed as a verb. AT: "continued to chase their enemies" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_abstractnouns]])
These are the names of men. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])

tn.ref: Are the hands of Zebah and Zalmunna now in your hand?
tn.text: The leaders use a question to emphasize that the Israelites have not yet captured Zebah and Zalumnna. AT: "You have not captured Zebah and Zalmunna yet." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])

tn.ref: Are the hands of Zebah and Zalmunna
tn.text: Here "hands" refer to the whole body. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
Here "hand" represents power or control. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: Why should we give bread to your army?
tn.text: The leaders use a question to emphasize that they have no reason to give bread to the Israelites. AT: "We see no reason to give bread to your army." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])

tn.ref: I will tear your skin with the desert thorns and briers
tn.text: The full meaning of this statement can be made explicit. AT: "I will make whips out of desert thorns and briers and use them to beat you and cut you" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
sharp, pointed pieces on vines or tree limbs that stick out and can cut people and animals
Here "He" refers to Gideon. Gideon represents the soldiers following him. AT: "They left there" or "Gideon and his 300 men left there" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
The name of a place. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])

tn.ref: and spoke to the people there in the same way
tn.text: You can make clear the understood information. AT: "and asked for food there in the same way" or "and he also asked them for food" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_ellipsis]])

tn.ref: When I come again in peace
tn.text: This is a polite way of referring to the defeat of his enemies. AT: "After I have completely defeated the Midian army" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_euphemism]])

tn.ref: I will pull down this tower
tn.text: Here "I" represents Gideon and his men. AT: "My men and I will pull down this tower" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
This word is used here to mark a break in the storyline. Here the narrator starts to tell a new part of the story.

tn.ref: men who were trained to fight with the sword
tn.text: This is a way of referring to soldiers. AT: "soldiers" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])

Here "Gideon" represents all of his soldiers. AT: "Gideon and his soldiers went up" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
Here "He" refers to Gideon who represents all of his soldiers. AT: "Gideon and his soldiers defeated" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])

tn.ref: Gideon took ... he punished ... he pulled
tn.text: Here "Gideon" represents his soldiers. AT: "Gideon and his soldiers took ... they punished ... they pulled" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])

This is the name of Gideon's son. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])

tn.text: This implies that they want Gideon's descendants to rule over them after he dies. AT: "you and your descendants after you die" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])

tn.ref: out of the hand of Midian
tn.text: Here "hand" represents the power of Midian over Israel. AT: "from the power of Midian" or "from Midian" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
Here "Midian" represents the people of Midian. AT: "of the Midianites" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
"Gideon said to the men of Israel"
jewelry worn on the ear

tn.text: Here the narrator tells background information about the Midianites. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:writing_background]])
clothing made from a large piece of fabric and worn over the shoulders as a coat

tn.text: This speaks of Gideon and his family being tempted to worship the ephod as if the ephod were a hunter's snare that would trap them. AT: "It became a temptation for Gideon and his family" or "Gideon and his family sinned by worshiping it" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
Here "his house" represents Gideon's family. AT: "for his family" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
